revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{notability|Products|date=April 2013}} {{refimprove|date=April 2013}} }} {{Infobox video game |title = Jonah Lomu Rugby |image = File:Johna lomu rugby cover.jpg | caption = |developer = [[Rage Software]] |publisher = [[Codemasters]] |designer = |released = March 31, 1997 |genre = [[Sports game|Rugby union]] |modes = [[Single-player]], [[multiplayer]] |platforms = [[DOS]], [[PlayStation (console)|PlayStation]], [[Sega Saturn]] }}
'''''Jonah Lomu Rugby''''' is a video game released in 1997. It was developed by [[Rage Software]] and published by [[Codemasters]]. It was released on [[DOS]], [[PlayStation (console)|PlayStation]] and [[Sega Saturn]]. Its title is a reference to former [[All Blacks]] winger [[Jonah Lomu]].
Following the 2003 closure of Rage Software, several members of the game's development team went on to work on ''[[World Championship Rugby]]''.<ref>{{cite web |last=Calvert |first=Justin |date=21 November 2003 |url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/world-championship-rugby-announced/1100-6084136/ |title=World Championship Rugby announced [date mislabeled as "November 24, 2003"] |website=[[GameSpot]] |accessdate=1 August 2016}}</ref>
==Gameplay== The game has support for up to four players.<ref name=SSM21>{{cite magazine |first=Matt |last=Yeo |title=Men in Black |magazine=[[Sega Saturn Magazine]] |issue=21|publisher=[[Emap International Limited]] |date=July 1997|pages=48-51}}</ref> There are a number of playable modes - including knock-out, [[Rugby World Cup|World Cup]], regional competitions as well as historical matches.
==Development== Rage Software head Trevor Williams recounted, "We wanted a game that stayed true to the rules, but was easy to pick up and play without a complete understanding of all the ins and outs."<ref name=SSM20>{{cite magazine |title=Preview: Jonah Lomu Rugby|magazine=[[Sega Saturn Magazine]]|issue=20|publisher=[[Emap International Limited]] |date=June 1997|pages=32-33}}</ref>
''Jonah Lomu Rugby'' was the first [[rugby union]] game released on the [[Sega Saturn|Saturn]]<ref name=SSMrev/> or [[PlayStation (console)|PlayStation]] platforms. Programmers Tony McCabe and Antonio Argentieri explained that rugby video games are more difficult to make than other sports games, since the heavy specialization of the different players means a number of different AIs need to be designed and programmed to run simultaneously.<ref name=SSM20/> The [[Scrum (rugby union)|scrum]] was remodeled more than five times in an effort to make it work in play.<ref name=SSM21/>
Commentary for the game was supplied by [[Bill McLaren]] and [[Bill Beaumont]].<ref name=SSM20/>
The Saturn version was slated for release in June 1997, but the date was pushed back to September 1997.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=First the Bad News |magazine=[[Sega Saturn Magazine]] |issue=22|publisher=[[Emap International Limited]] |date=August 1997|page=11}}</ref>
==Reception== Matt Yeo gave the Saturn version a rave review in ''[[Sega Saturn Magazine]]'', saying it "features one of the most innovative and easy to use game play systems ever utilised in a sports game." He particularly noted the use of on-screen menus during pauses in the game's action, saying they enable newcomers to more easily come to grips with the game by presenting rugby's complicated rules in a simplified, leisurely form. He also praised the four-player support, audio commentary, and dramatic weather conditions, and gave the game a score of 91%.<ref name=SSMrev>{{cite magazine |first=Matt|last=Yeo |title=Review: Jonah Lomu Rugby |magazine=[[Sega Saturn Magazine]] |issue=21|publisher=[[Emap International Limited]] |date=July 1997|pages=62-63}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.gamespot.com/ps/sports/jonahlomurugby/index.html ''Jonah Lomu Rugby''] at [[GameSpot]] * [http://psx.ign.com/objects/010/010535.html ''Jonah Lomu Rugby''] at [[IGN]] * {{moby game|id=/jonah-lomu-rugby |name=Jonah Lomu Rugby}} {{Rugby Union video games}}
[[Category:1997 video games]] [[Category:DOS games]] [[Category:PlayStation (console) games]] [[Category:Rugby union video games]] [[Category:Sega Saturn games]] [[Category:Video games developed in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Video games set in New Zealand]] [[Category:Codemasters games]] [[Category:Rage Software games]] [[Category:Video games based on real people]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of sportspeople|Lomu]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of men|Lomu]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of New Zealand people|Lomu]] [[Category:Black people in art]]

'''Karl Barth's views on Mary''' agreed with much [[Roman Catholic]] dogma but disagreed with the Catholic veneration of [[Mary (mother of Jesus)|Mary]]. [[Karl Barth|Barth]], a leading 20th-century theologian, was a [[Reformed Protestant]]. Aware of the common dogmatic tradition of the early Church, Barth fully accepted the dogma of Mary as the [[Mother of God]]. Through Mary, Jesus belongs to the human race. Through Jesus, Mary is Mother of God.
==Background==
===Theology of Karl Barth=== Karl Barth (May 10, 1886 – December 10, 1968) a [[Switzerland|Swiss]] [[Reformed]] theologian, was one of the most important Christian thinkers of the 20th century. Beginning with his experience as a pastor, he rejected the predominant [[liberal Christianity|liberal]] theology typical of 19th-century [[Protestantism]], especially [[Germany|German]], and instead embarked on a unique theological path, often labelled [[neo-orthodoxy]] by critics (a label emphatically rejected by Barth himself), that emphasized the sovereignty of God particularly through his innovative doctrine of [[predestination|election]]. Barth's theology swept through Europe and Britain.
Barth was originally trained in German [[Protestantism|Protestant]] [[Liberal Christianity|Liberalism]] under such teachers as [[Wilhelm Herrmann]], but reacted against this theology at the time of the [[World War I|First World War]]. His reaction was fed by several factors, including his commitment to the German and Swiss [[International League of Religious Socialists|Religious Socialist]] movement surrounding men like [[Hermann Kutter]], the influence of the [[Biblical Realism]] movement surrounding men like [[Christoph Blumhardt]] and [[Søren Kierkegaard]], and the impact of the [[skepticism|skeptical philosophy]] of [[Franz Overbeck]].
===Epistle to the Romans=== In his commentary ''[[The Epistle to the Romans]]'' (Ger. ''Der Römerbrief''; particularly in the thoroughly re-written second edition of 1922) Barth argued that the God who is revealed in the cross of [[Jesus]] challenges and overthrows any attempt to ally God with human cultures, achievements, or possessions. Many theologians believe this work to be the most important theological treatise since [[Friedrich Schleiermacher]]'s ''[[On Religion: Speeches to its Cultured Despisers]].''
In the decade following the First World War, Barth was linked with a number of other theologians, actually very diverse in outlook, who had reacted against their teachers' liberalism, in a movement known as "[[Dialectical Theology]]" <ref>(Ger. ''Dialektische Theologie'').</ref> Other members of the movement included [[Rudolf Bultmann]], [[Eduard Thurneysen]], [[Emil Brunner]], and [[Friedrich Gogarten]].
==Marian views==
===The nativity mystery===
* ''The nativity mystery “conceived from the [[Holy Spirit]] and born from the [[Virgin Mary]]”, means, that God became human, truly human out of his own grace. The miracle of the existence of Jesus , his “climbing down of God” is: Holy Spirit and Virgin Mary! Here is a human being, the Virgin Mary, and as he comes from God, Jesus comes also from this human being. Born of the Virgin Mary means a human origin for God. Jesus Christ is not only truly God, he is human like every one of us. He is human without limitation. He is not only similar to us, he is like us''.<ref>Barth, Dogmatik im Grundriss, 1947, 125,127</ref>
This means to Barth, God's presence in our world, His presence as man among men and therefore God's revelation to humanity. It also means humanity's reconciliation with God. To Barth, this happened and still happens, it is the substance of the Christmas message.
This God is conceived where we all are conceived. He is born of Mary. She who conceived and bore Him, plays our part in the wonder of Christmas, for it concerns us. God has come to us. "Disguised in our flesh and blood, is the Eternal God."
=== Virgin Birth === The [[Nicene Creed]] says: ''Et incarnatus est de Spiritu Sancto ex Maria virgine et homo factus est'' ("and he [God the Son] became body from the Virgin Mary and was made man"). In Barth's theology – in contrast to much of the contemporary liberal theology – this statement is interpreted to mean the [[dogma]] of the [[Virgin birth of Jesus|Virgin Birth]]. It means that Jesus as a human does not have a father, in the same way that as the Son of God he has no mother. The Holy Spirit, through whom Mary conceived, is not just any spirit, it is God himself whose act must be understood spiritually and not physically.<ref>Barth, Kirchliche Dogmatic I, 2, 219</ref> Mary is "full of grace" according to Barth, but this grace is not earned but totally given to her. This is quite similar to Catholic teaching, in which Mary, "by sheer grace," received the fullness of grace from God at the moment of her conception, that she might give her consent at the annunciation.<ref>Catechism of the Catholic Church, 722</ref> Barth argues that the Church adopted its doctrine of the [[perpetual virginity of Mary]] not because of Mary, but in defence of its [[Christology]].
=== Mother of God ===
Karl Barth states that as a Christian and theologian, he does not reject the description of Mary as the "Mother of God." To him, this is a legitimate expression of Christological truth. The description of Mary as the "Mother of God" was and is sensible, permissible and necessary as an auxiliary Christological proposition.<ref>Church Dogmatics, I, 2, Edinburgh: T. & T. Clark, 1963, 138)</ref><ref name="Barth2004-1">{{cite book|author=Karl Barth|title=Church Dogmatics: The doctrine of the word of God (2 pts.)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Po0rhLSFx0wC&pg=PA138|date=1 January 2004|publisher=Continuum|isbn=978-0-567-05069-4|pages=138–}}</ref>
===Critique of the Catholic view === Barth on the other hand sees the term "Mother of God," as "being overloaded by the so-called Mariology of the Roman Catholic Church".<ref>Church Dogmatics, 138</ref> He considered the Roman Catholic veneration of Mary a terrible mistake and heresy.
* ''Where ever Mary is venerated, and devotion to her takes place, there the Church of Christ does not exist''.<ref>Barth, Kirchliche Dogmatik, I, 2, 154</ref><ref name="Barth2010">{{cite book|author=Karl Barth|title=Church Dogmatics Study Edition 3: The Doctrine of the Word of God I.2 § 13-15|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=APXR1E0m_AkC&pg=PA145|date=2 September 2010|publisher=Continuum|isbn=978-0-567-02766-5|pages=145–}}</ref> * ''Mariology is an excrescence, i.e., a diseased construct of theological thought. Excrescences must be excised.'' <ref>Barth, Kirchliche Dogmatik, I, 2, 153</ref><ref name="Barth2004">{{cite book|author=Karl Barth|title=Church Dogmatics: The doctrine of the word of God (2 pts.)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Po0rhLSFx0wC&pg=PA139|date=1 January 2004|publisher=Continuum|isbn=978-0-567-05069-4|pages=139–}}</ref>
He warns however, of extending this critique too far: {{quote|It is not recommended that we should base our repudiation [of Marian doctrine] on the assertion that there has taken place here an irruption from the heathen sphere, an adoption of the idea, current in many non-Christian religions, of a more or less central and original female or mother deity. In dogmatics you can establish everything and nothing from parallels from the history of religions.<ref>Church Dogmatics, Vol. 1, p. 143).</ref>}}
And, Barth equally attacks Protestant theology on this issue: "For justice sake, one has to say, that the Protestant rejection of Roman Catholic mariology and Marian cult is dishonest, as long as Protestantism is caught in the same unreal problem".<ref>Barth, Kirchliche Dogmatic, I,2,160</ref> He was a close friend of [[Hans Urs von Balthasar]], who published about him. Barth’s dogmatic theology was partly based on [[Thomas Aquinas]], although he departed from Aquinas on many characteristically Catholic points.
==See also== * [[Blessed Virgin Mary]] * [[Theotokos]] * [[Marian doctrines of the Catholic Church|Marian doctrines of the Roman Catholic Church]] * [[Mariology (Roman Catholic)]]
==Sources == * Karl Barth, ''Die kirchliche Dogmatik,'' Zollikon, Vol.I-IV, 1932-1955
== References == {{reflist}} {{Virgin Mary}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Barth, Karl}} [[Category:Calvinist theology]] [[Category:Protestant views of Mary]] [[Category:Karl Barth|Mary]] [[Category:Point of view]]

revision.text:
{{short description|genre of music from Spanish and Portuguese areas or sung in either language}} {{about|a genre in the music industry|music from Latin America|Music of Latin America}}{{Other uses}} {{Use mdy dates|date=December 2017}} {{Infobox music genre |native_name={{lang|es|Música latina}} |name=Latin music |color=blue |bgcolor=yellow |stylistic_origins = {{hlist|[[Music of Latin America|Latin American music]]|[[Music of Spain|Spanish music]]|[[Music of Portugal|Portuguese music]]}} |cultural_origins = Mid-1900s in the United States |derivatives = {{hlist|[[Latin pop]]|[[Latin ballad]]}} |current_year = yes |current_year_title = Latin music |other_topics=The American music industry commonly divides Latin music into four subcategories: [[Latin pop]], [[Regional Mexican]], [[Tropical music]], and Urban ([[Reggaeton]] & [[Latin trap]])}}
'''Latin music''' ([[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] and {{lang-es|música latina}})<!--Please do not capitalize the "l" in "latina" as this is how it is spelled in Spanish and Portuguese--> is a genre used by the [[music industry]] as a catch-all term for music that comes from Spanish- and Portuguese-speaking areas of the world, namely Ibero America, Spain and Portugal, as well as music sung in either language.<ref name="morales">{{cite book |last1=Morales |first1=Ed |title=The Latin beat: The Rhythms and Roots of Latin music From Bossa Nova to Salsa and Beyond |date=2003 |publisher=[[Da Capo Press]] |location=Cambridge, MA |isbn=978-0-306-81018-3 |page=xiii |edition=1. Da Capo Press |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Lpv25quOSnwC&lpg=PR13 |accessdate=September 10, 2015 |quote=Including Spain, there are twenty-two predominately Spanish-speaking countries, and there are many more styles of Latin music.}}</ref><ref name="stavans">{{cite book |last1=Stavans |first1=llan |authorlink=Ilan Stavans |title=Latin music: musicians, genres, and themes |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qE-LBAAAQBAJ&lpg=PP1&pg=PR18#v=onepage&q&f=false |date=2014 |publisher=[[ABC-CLIO]] |location=Santa Barbara, California: |isbn=978-0-313-34396-4 |page=xviii, 838 |accessdate=October 30, 2014}}</ref><ref name="vivalatino">{{cite journal |last1=Lawrence |first1=Larry |last2=Wright |first2=Tom |title=¡Viva Latino! |journal=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=January 26, 1985 |volume=97 |issue=4 |pages=53, 62 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7CQEAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PP1&pg=PT109#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate=April 9, 2015 |issn=0006-2510}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Flores |first1=Juan |last2=Rosaldo |first2=Renato |title=A Companion to Latina/o Studies. |date=2007 |publisher=Blackwell Pub. |location=Oxford |isbn=978-0-470-65826-0 |page=50 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=i3a1qVqHoJAC&lpg=PP1&pg=PA50#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate=September 10, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Llewellyn |first1=Howell |title=ShowMarket to Focus on Development of Latin Music |journal=Billboard |date=November 25, 1995 |volume=107 |issue=47 |page=72 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Pw0EAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA1&pg=PA72#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate=July 30, 2015 |issn=0006-2510}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Arenas |first1=Fernando |title=Lusophone Africa: Beyond Independence |date=2011 |publisher=University of Minnesota Press |location=Minneapolis |isbn=978-0-8166-6983-7 |page=220 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eThbx7A_mEEC&lpg=PP1&pg=PA220#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate=September 10, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Stavans |first1=Ilan |last2=Augenbraum |first2=Harold |title=Encyclopedia Latina : history, culture, and society in the United States |date=2005 |publisher=Grolier Academic Reference |location=Danbury, Conn. |isbn=978-0-7172-5818-5 |page=201 |quote=The term Latin music identifies a wide range of genres and styles generated in Latin America and the Iberian Peninsula}}</ref> In the United States, the music industry defines Latin music as any recording sung mostly in Spanish regardless of its genre or the artist's nationality.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Edwards |first1=Bob |title=Profile: Latin Grammys at the Staples Center in Los Angeles |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-31750825.html |website=[[NPR]] |accessdate=August 7, 2015 |date=September 13, 2000 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160225024337/https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-31750825.html |archivedate=February 25, 2016 |subscription=yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Barkley |first1=Elizabeth F. |title=Crossroads: the Multicultural Roots of America's Popular Music |date=2007 |publisher=Pearson Prentice Hall |location=Upper Saddle River, NJ |isbn=978-0-13-193073-5 |page=232 |edition=2nd |quote=The U.S. record industry defines Latin music as simply any release with lyrics that are mostly in Spanish.}}</ref> The [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA) and [[Billboard (magazine)|''Billboard'']] magazine use this definition of Latin music to track sales of Spanish-language records in the US.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Valdes-Rodriguez |first1=Alisa |title=The Loud and Quiet Explosions |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1999/dec/26/entertainment/ca-47489 |accessdate=October 28, 2015 |work=Los Angeles Times |publisher=Tribune Company |date=December 26, 1999}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.billboard.com/biz/articles/news/1099596/latin-sales-down-slightly-in-2011-digital-latin-sales-up |title=Latin Sales Down Slightly In 2011, Digital Latin Sales Up |last=Cobo |first=Leila |authorlink=Leila Cobo |journal=Billboard |date=January 5, 2012 |accessdate=September 30, 2015}}</ref> Spain, Brazil, Mexico and the United States are the largest Latin music markets in the world.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Llewellyn |first1=Howell |title=The Spanish Market Looks To Export Artists |journal=Billboard |date=November 11, 2000 |volume=112 |issue=46 |page=78 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5RAEAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA7&pg=PA78#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate=April 9, 2015 |issn=0006-2510}}</ref>
== Contemporary usage == Since the late 1990s, the US has had a substantially rising population of "Latinos",<ref>{{cite book |last1=Suárez-Orozco |first1=Marcelo |title=Latinos: Remaking America |date=2008 |publisher=University of California Press |isbn=978-0-520-25827-3}}</ref> a term popularized since the 1960s due to the wrong and confusing use of the term "[[Spaniards|Spanish]]" and the more proper but less popular term "[[Hispanic]]".<ref>{{cite book |last1=González |first1=Juan |title=Harvest of Empire: A History of Latinos in America |date=2011 |publisher=Penguin Books |isbn=978-0-14-311928-9}}</ref> A great part of the English-speaking media started to refer to any kind of music featuring Spanish vocals as "Latin music".<ref>{{cite book |last1=Avant-Mier |first1=Roberto |title=Rock the Nation: Latin/o Identities and the Latin Rock Diaspora |date=2010 |publisher=Continuum Publishing Corporation}}</ref>
== International organizations and conferences == Major record labels such as [[Universal Music Group]], [[Sony Music]], and [[Warner Music]] often have two divisions dedicated to the Latin market: one which focuses on Latin America and the Iberian Peninsula,<ref>{{cite web |title=Billboard's Latin Power Players List Revealed |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/latin/6648545/billboard-latin-power-players-list-2015?page=0%2C0 |website=Billboard |publisher=Prometheus Global Media |accessdate=July 30, 2015 |date=July 30, 2015}}</ref> and the other for the Hispanic market in the United States.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Rodriguez |first1=Rene |title=The Miami sound is gone. But the beat goes on. Here is what replaced it |url=http://www.miamiherald.com/entertainment/music-news-reviews/article85906062.html |accessdate=August 15, 2016 |work=[[Miami Herald]] |date=June 26, 2016}}</ref> Since 1990, ''Billboard'' has held the Latin Music Conference every year. The week-long conference features speakers including key personnel such as executives and producers from the Latin music industry and notable artists in the Latin music scene. The conference concludes with the annual [[Billboard Latin Music Awards|''Billboard'' Latin Music Awards]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Cobo |first1=Leila |title=Countdown to the 25th Annual Billboard Latin Music Conference: 1989–1993 |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/events/latin-awards/6029529/countdown-to-the-25th-annual-billboard-latin-music-conference |website=Billboard |publisher=Prometheus Global Media |accessdate=26 May 2018 |date=1 April 2014}}</ref> In 2000, the [[Latin Recording Academy]] inaugurated the [[Latin Grammy Award]]s to recognize musicians who perform in Spanish or Portuguese.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2000/sep/12/news/ss-19479 |title=One Little Word, Yet It Means So Much |last=Valdes-Rodriguez |first=Alisa |work=Los Angeles Times |publisher=Tribune Company |date=June 25, 1999 |accessdate=December 25, 2013}}</ref> The awards mainly encompass music from Latin America, Spain, Portugal, and the United States.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Billboard Spotlights Spain & Portugal |journal=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=November 20, 1999 |volume=111 |issue=47 |page=91 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fwgEAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PP1&pg=PA91#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate=September 3, 2015 |issn=0006-2510}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Fernandez |first1=Enrique |title=After Birthing Pains, Latin Grammys Should Grow Strong |url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/2000-03-05/entertainment/0003031244_1_latin-music-latin-academy-latin-grammy-show |accessdate=July 31, 2015 |work=Sun-Sentinel |publisher=McClatchy Company |date=March 5, 2000}}</ref> The [[Latin Songwriters Hall of Fame]] was established in 2012 to recognize songwriters from Spanish- and Portuguese-speaking regions around the world.<ref name="miaminews">{{cite news |author1=S. Pajot |title=Latin Songwriters Hall of Fame Launches in Miami, Announces 2013 Nominees |url=http://blogs.miaminewtimes.com/crossfade/2012/12/latin_songwriters_hall_of_fame_2013_nominees.php |accessdate=October 30, 2014 |work=[[Miami New Times]] |publisher=[[Voice Media Group]] |date=December 12, 2012}}</ref>
== History == === 1940s–1950s === The term "Latin music" originated from the US due to the growing influence of [[Hispanic and Latino American]]s in the American music market, with notable pioneers including [[Xavier Cugat]] (1940s) and [[Tito Puente]] (1950s) and then accelerating in later decades.<ref name="stavans" /><ref name="vivalatino" /> As one author explained the rising popularity from the 1940s: "Latin America, the one part of the world not engulfed in [[World War II]], became a favorite topic for songs and films for Americans who wanted momentarily to forget about the conflagration."<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_Ynt6yc5nGQC&pg=PT263 |title=Skylark: The Life and Times of Johnny Mercer |first=Philip |last=Furia |publisher=Macmillan |year=2004 |isbn=978-1-4668-1923-8 |page=263}}</ref> Wartime propaganda for America's "[[Good Neighbor Policy]]" further enhanced the cultural impact.<ref>{{cite book |first=Brian |last=O'Neil |chapter=Carmen Miranda: The High Price of Fame and Bananas |title=Latina Legacies |editor1-first=Vicki L. |editor1-last=Ruiz |editor2-first=Virginia |editor2-last=Sánchez Korrol |publisher=Oxford University Press |year=2005 |page=195 |isbn=978-0-19-515398-9 |quote=the power that Hollywood films could exert in the two-pronged campaign to win the hearts and minds of Latin Americans and to convince Americans of the benefits of Pan-American friendship}}</ref>
=== 1960s === The Brazilian [[bossa nova]] became widespread in Latin America and later became an international trend, led especially by [[Antônio Carlos Jobim]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Taffet |first1=Jeffrey |last2=Watcher |first2=Dustin |title=Latin America and the United States: A Documentary History |date=2011 |publisher=Oxford University Press |location=New York |isbn=978-0-19-538568-7 |edition=2nd |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OhC9DgAAQBAJ&lpg=PP1&pg=PT419#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate=June 7, 2017}}</ref> [[Rock en español]] became popular with the younger generation of Latinos in Latin America,<ref>{{cite book |authorlink1=Cordelia Candelaria |last1=Candelaria |first1=Cordelia|editor1-last=Candelaria|editor1-first=Cordelia|editor2-last=García|editor2-first=Peter J.|editor3-last=Aldama|editor3-first=Arturo J. |title=Encyclopedia of Latino Popular Culture in the United States |volume=2 |date=2004 |publisher=Greenwood Press |location=Westport, CT |isbn=978-0-313-32215-0 |page=690 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3uD6PKXl3q4C&lpg=PP1&pg=PA690#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> notably including Argentine bands such as [[Almendra (band)|Almendra]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Olsen |first1=Dale |last2=Sheehy |first2=Daniel E. |title=The Garland handbook of Latin American music |date=2008 |publisher=Routledge |location=New York |isbn=978-0-415-96101-1 |page=458 |edition=2nd |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RK6TAgAAQBAJ&lpg=PP1&pg=PA458#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate=June 7, 2017}}</ref> Mexican-American [[Latin rock]] guitarist [[Carlos Santana]] began his decades of popularity.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/carlos-santana-mn0000175196/biography |title=Carlos Santana: Biography |last=Ruhlmann |first=William |year=2003 |publisher=AllMusic |accessdate=June 7, 2017}}</ref>
=== 1970s === [[File:Julio Iglesias (Spanje), Bestanddeelnr 923-3697.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Spanish singer [[Julio Iglesias]] was recognized by the ''[[Guinness World Records]]'' as the best-selling male Latin artist of all time in 2013.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/news/2013/4/julio-iglesias-receives-world-record-certificate-in-beijing-47865/ |title=Julio Iglesias receives world record certificate in Beijing |publisher=Guinness World Record |date=April 2, 2013 |accessdate=December 24, 2013}}</ref>]] [[Salsa music]] became the dominant genre of tropical music in the 1970s. [[Fania Records]] was credited for popularizing salsa music, with acts such as [[Rubén Blades]], [[Héctor Lavoe]], and [[Celia Cruz]] expanding the audience.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Bernstein |first1=Arthur |last2=Sekine |first2=Naoki |last3=Weismann |first3=Dick |title=The Global Music Industry Three Perspectives. |date=2013 |publisher=Taylor and Francis |location=Hoboken |isbn=978-1-135-92248-1 |page=78 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oTnaAAAAQBAJ&lpg=PP1&pg=PA78#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate=June 6, 2017}}</ref> In the late 1970s, an influx of balladeers from Spain such as [[Julio Iglesias]], [[Camilo Sesto]], and [[Raphael (singer)|Raphael]] established their presence on the music charts both in Latin America and the US Latin market.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Salaverri |first1=Fernando |title=Spain Establishing the Latin European Link |journal=Billboard |date=November 3, 1979 |volume=91 |issue=44 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zCQEAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PP1&pg=PT115#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate=March 24, 2017 |issn=0006-2510}}</ref> In 1972, [[OTI Festival]] was established by the [[Organización de Telecomunicaciones de Iberoamérica]] as a songwriting contest to connect the Ibero-American countries (Latin America, Spain, and Portugal) together. Ramiro Burr of ''Billboard'' noted that the contest was considered to be the "largest and most prestigious songwriting festival in the Latin music world".<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Burr |first1=Ramiro |title=Mexican Quartet Captures Top OTI Prize |journal=Billboard |date=January 5, 1991 |page=61 }}</ref>
=== 1980s === In the 1980s, the [[Latin ballad]] continued to be the main form of Latin pop music, with [[Juan Gabriel]], [[José José]], Julio Iglesias, [[Roberto Carlos (singer)|Roberto Carlos]], and [[José Luis Rodríguez (singer)|José Luis Rodríguez]] dominating the charts.<ref>{{cite journal |url=https://books.google.com/?id=Rg8EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA28&dq=jose+jose+el+principe+de+la+cancion#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=The Prince's 40-Year Reign: A Billboard Q&A |last=Cobo |first=Leila |volume=115 |issue=48 |page=28 |date=November 29, 2003 |journal=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] }}</ref> [[Salsa music]] lost some traction, and its musical style changed to a slower rhythm with more emphasis on romantic lyrics. This became known as the [[salsa romantica]] era.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Pietrobruno |first1=Sheenagh |title=Salsa and Its Transnational Moves |date=2006 |publisher=Lexington Books |location=Lanham |isbn=978-0-7391-6058-9}}</ref>
=== 1990s === [[Bolero]] music saw a resurgence of popularity with the younger audience. Mexican singer [[Luis Miguel]] was credited for the renewed interest due to the success of his album, ''[[Romance (Luis Miguel album)|Romance]]'' (1991), a collection of classics covered by the artist.<ref name="ageless">{{cite journal |url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Ageless+romance+with+bolero.-a017482173 |title=Ageless Romance with Bolero |last=Holston |first=Mark |journal=Américas |date=September 1, 1995 |accessdate=March 21, 2015}}</ref> By the mid-1990s, [[Latin pop]] music was dominated by younger artists such as [[Menudo (band)|Menudo]] alumnus [[Ricky Martin]], Colombian teen [[Shakira]], and Julio's son [[Enrique Iglesias]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Powell |first1=John |title=Encyclopedia of North American immigration |date=2005 |publisher=Facts On File |location=New York |isbn=978-1-4381-1012-7 |page=92 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VNCX6UsdZYkC&lpg=PP1&pg=PA92#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> Around the same time, artists from Italy such as [[Eros Ramazzotti]], [[Laura Pausini]], and [[Nek]] successfully [[crossover (music)|crossed over]] to the Latin music field by recording Spanish-language versions of their songs.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Obejas |first1=Achy |authorlink1=Achy Obejas |title=Italian Artists Conquer Latin Music Charts |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1999-04-04/news/9904040139_1_latin-music-eros-ramazzotti-italian |accessdate=January 4, 2015 |work=[[Chicago Tribune]] |publisher=[[Tribune Company]] |date=April 4, 1999}}</ref> In the [[Regional Mexican]] field, [[Tejano music|Tejano]] became the most prominent genre. [[Selena]] helped push Tejano music into the mainstream market with her albums ''[[Entre a Mi Mundo]]'' (1992) and ''[[Amor Prohibido]]'' (1994), although the genre's popularity declined following [[Murder of Selena|her death]] in 1995.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Saldana |first1=Hector |title=Tejano music enjoyed a decade-long golden age |url=http://www.mysanantonio.com/news/local/article/Tejano-music-enjoyed-a-decade-long-golden-age-6447952.php |accessdate=March 24, 2016 |work=[[San Antonio Express-News]] |date=August 16, 2015}}</ref> In the [[tropical music]] field, [[merengue music|merengue]], which gained attention in the 1980s, rivaled [[salsa music|salsa]] in popularity.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Rodriguez |first1=Nelson |title=A look at contemporary Merengue. (género de música Latinoamericana)(TA: Latin American music genre) |journal=[[Latin Beat Magazine]] |date=September 1, 1998 |url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-21139246.html |accessdate=May 18, 2017 |subscription=yes}}</ref>
=== 2000s === In the mid-2000s, [[reggaeton]] became popular in the mainstream market, with [[Daddy Yankee]], [[Don Omar]], and [[Wisin & Yandel]] considered to be the frontiers of the genre.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Resto-Montero |first1=Gabriela |title=The Unstoppable Rise of Reggaeton |url=http://fusion.kinja.com/the-unstoppable-rise-of-reggaeton-1793854249 |website=Fusion |accessdate=May 19, 2017 |date=January 25, 2016}}</ref> In the tropical music scene, [[bachata (music)|bachata]] music became popular in the field, with artists such as [[Monchy & Alexandra]] and [[Aventura (band)|Aventura]] finding success in the urban areas of Latin America.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Cobo |first1=Leila |title=Tropical Paradise |journal=Billboard |date=August 15, 2009 |volume=121 |issue=32 |page=31 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AHcbf1oaC8UC&lpg=PP1&pg=PT30#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate=May 19, 2017 |issn=0006-2510}}</ref> [[Banda (music)|Banda]] was the dominant genre in the Regional Mexican music field.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Henderson |first1=Alex |title=Me Cambiaste la Vida – Rogelio Martinez |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/me-cambiaste-la-vida-mw0000474613 |website=AllMusic |accessdate=May 19, 2017}}</ref>
=== 2010s === By the turn of the decade, the Latin music field became dominated by up-tempo rhythms, including electropop, reggaeton, urban, banda and contemporary bachata music, as Latin ballads and crooners fell out of favor among U.S. Latin radio programmers.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Cobo |first1=Leila |authorlink1=Leila Cobo |title=Latin Noise: We Want Our Ballads |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/latin-notas/6244251/latin-music-we-want-our-ballads |website=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]] |accessdate=September 8, 2015 |date=September 10, 2014}}</ref> [[Streaming media|Streaming]] has become the dominant form of revenue in the Latin music industry in the United States, Latin America and Spain.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Melendez |first1=Angel |title=Why Are Spanish Songs More Popular on YouTube? Billboard's Leila Cobo Knows |url=http://www.miaminewtimes.com/music/leila-cobo-talks-spanish-youtube-explosion-at-billboard-latin-music-conference-and-awards-2017-9293723 |accessdate=June 12, 2017 |work=Miami New Times |date=April 25, 2017}}</ref> [[Latin trap]] gained mainstream attention in the mid-2010s with notable artists such as [[Ozuna (singer)|Ozuna]], [[Bad Bunny]], Anuel AA and [[Noriel]].<ref name="fader">{{cite web |title=Trap's Latin American Takeover |url=http://www.thefader.com/2017/07/05/traps-latin-american-takeover-spotify-playlist-trap-land |website=The Fader |accessdate=December 29, 2017}}</ref>
== See also == {{Portal|Latin music}} * [[:Category:Years in Latin music]] * [[Billboard Top Latin Albums]] * [[Hot Latin Songs]] * [[List of best-selling Latin albums in the United States]] * [[OTI Festival]]
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
== Further reading == * {{cite book |last1=Stavans |first1=Ilan |authorlink=Ilan Stavans |title=Latin music: musicians, genres, and themes |date=2014 |publisher=[[ABC-CLIO]] |location=Santa Barbara, California: |isbn=978-0-313-34396-4}} * {{cite book |author=Morales, Ed |title=The Latin Beat |year=2003 |publisher=Da Capo Press |isbn=978-0-306-81018-3}} * {{cite journal |title=1992 International Buyer's Guide to Latin Music |year=1992 |journal=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |issn=1074-746X}}
== External links == * [http://latinmusic.about.com/od/basics101/a/What-Is-Latin-Music.htm What Is Latin Music?] [[About.com]] * [https://www.allmusic.com/genre/latin-ma0000002692 Latin Music Genre Overview] [[AllMusic]] * [https://www.billboard.com/latin Latin Music] ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' * [https://www.latingrammy.com/en Latin Grammy]

page.title: List of actors with two or more Star Awards in acting categories

revision.comment: /* top */clean up, replaced: You Can Be An Angel → You Can Be an Angel
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2018}} [[Mediacorp]] has given [[Star Awards]] to actors and actresses for their performances in drama serials since its inception. Throughout the history of the Star Awards, there have been actors and actresses who have received multiple Star Awards for [[Star Awards for Best Actor|Best Actor]], [[Star Awards for Best Actress|Best Actress]], [[Star Awards for Best Supporting Actor|Best Supporting Actor]], or [[Star Awards for Best Supporting Actress|Best Supporting Actress]]. {{As of|2018}}, 20 actors and actresses have received two or more Star Awards in acting categories. [[Chen Hanwei]] and [[Xie Shaoguang]] lead the way with seven awards (five Best Actor awards and two Best Supporting Actor awards), while [[Xiang Yun]] has won four Best Supporting Actress awards. Xie was the first to receive four awards in [[Star Awards 1998|1998]], followed by Xiang Yun in [[Star Awards 2009|2009]], and most recently Chen in [[Star Awards 2010|2010]]. Xie was also the first to receive five, six, and seven awards in 1999, [[Star Awards 2003|2003]] and [[Star Awards 2004|2004]] respectively. {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Actor/Actress !! Best Actor/Actress awards !! Best Supporting Actor/Actress awards !! Total awards !! Total nominations |- | [[Chen Hanwei]] 陈汉玮 | ''[[Love Me, Love Me Not (Singaporean TV series)|Love Me, Love Me Not]] 真爱无敌'' ([[Star Awards 2001|2001]])
''[[A Life of Hope]] 活下去'' ([[Star Awards 2005|2005]])
''[[By My Side (TV series)|By My Side]] 不凡的爱'' ([[Star Awards 2009|2009]])
''[[Daddy at Home]] 企鹅爸爸'' ([[Star Awards 2010|2010]])
''[[The Gentlemen (TV series)|The Gentlemen]] 来自水星的男人'' ([[Star Awards 2017|2017]]) | ''[[The Journey: Tumultuous Times]] 信约：动荡的年代'' ([[Star Awards 2015|2015]])
''[[The Lead]] 第一主角'' ([[Star Awards 2018|2018]]) | style="text-align:center;"| 7 | style="text-align:center;"| 14 |- | [[Xie Shaoguang]] 谢韶光 | ''The Last Rhythm 曲终魂断'' (1996)
''[[Stand by Me (TV series)|Stand by Me]] 家人有约'' ([[Star Awards 1998|1998]])
''[[Stepping Out (Singaporean TV series)|Stepping Out]] 出路'' (1999)
''[[Holland V (TV series)|Holland V]] 荷兰村'' ([[Star Awards 2003|2003]])
''[[Double Happiness (TV series)|Double Happiness I]] 喜临门I'' ([[Star Awards 2004|2004]]) | ''Larceny of Love 雌雄大盗'' (1995)
''[[The Golden Pillow]] 金枕头'' (1996) | style="text-align:center;"| 7 | style="text-align:center;"| 9 |- | [[Xiang Yun]] 向云 | | ''Around People's Park 珍珠街坊'' ([[Star Awards 1998|1998]])
''My Home Affairs 家事'' ([[Star Awards 2000|2000]])
''The Challenge 谁与争锋'' ([[Star Awards 2001|2001]])
''[[The Little Nyonya]] 小娘惹'' ([[Star Awards 2009|2009]]) | style="text-align:center;"| 4 | style="text-align:center;"| 12 |- | [[Chen Liping]] 陈莉萍 | ''[[Holland V (TV series)|Holland V]] 荷兰村'' ([[Star Awards 2003|2003]])
''[[Reunion Dinner]] 团圆饭'' ([[Star Awards 2010|2010]])
''[[The Dream Makers (TV series)|The Dream Makers]] 志在四方'' ([[Star Awards 20|2014]]) | | style="text-align:center;"| 3 | style="text-align:center;"| 11 |- | [[Tay Ping Hui]] 郑斌辉 | ''[[Bountiful Blessings]] 万福楼'' ([[Star Awards 2012|2012]]) | ''[[Stepping Out (Singaporean TV series)|Stepping Out]] 出路'' (1999)
''[[Unriddle 2]] 最火搭档2'' ([[Star Awards 2013|2013]]) | style="text-align:center;"| 3 | style="text-align:center;"| 11 |- | [[Li Nanxing]] 李南星 | ''Wounded Tracks 伤城记'' (1995)
''[[The Vagrant]] 豹子胆'' ([[Star Awards 2002|2002]])
''[[The Undisclosed]] 迷云二十天'' ([[Star Awards 2006|2006]]) | | style="text-align:center;"| 3 | style="text-align:center;"| 10 |- | [[Huang Biren]] 黄碧仁 | ''[[Stand by Me (TV series)|Stand by Me]] 家人有约'' ([[Star Awards 1998|1998]])
''[[Beautiful Connection]] 九层糕'' ([[Star Awards 2002|2002]])

page.title: List of books related to Buddhism

revision.comment: The revised edition of 'What the Buddha Taught' is published by Grove Press, not Oneworld Publications. I've also added the publisher for the other two titles listed.
/* [[Aeolic verse|Aeolics]] */Fixing [[Wikipedia:Disambiguation pages with links|links to disambiguation pages]] -- [[Alcaeus]] using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
The following [[meter (poetry)|meters]] were used in [[Ancient Greek literature|Greek poetry]] and adapted for [[Latin literature|Latin poetry]]:
==Major forms== *[[Dactylic hexameter]], the meter of the ''[[Iliad]]'', ''[[Odyssey]]'' and ''[[Aeneid]]'', used for epic and other narrative and didactic poetry *[[Elegiac couplet]], consisting of a line of dactylic hexameter and one of [[dactylic pentameter]], employed by [[Ovid]] for all his extant works except the ''[[Metamorphoses]]'' *[[Iambic trimeter]], the most common meter in the dialogue portions of tragedy and comedy
==[[Aeolic verse|Aeolics]]== *[[Glyconic]] and [[pherecratean]] *[[Asclepiad (poetry)|Asclepiad]] *[[Sapphic stanza]], so called for [[Sappho]] *[[Alcaic stanza]], so called for [[Alcaeus of Mytilene|Alcaeus]] *[[Hendecasyllabic verse]] *[[Adonean]]
==Other meters== *[[Choliamb]]ic, also known as '''limping iambs''' or '''scazon''' *[[Ionic meter|Ionic]] *[[Anacreonteus]] *[[Anapestic (Greek meter)|Anapestic]] *[[Trochaic (Greek meter)|Trochaic]] *[[Dactylo-epitrite]] *[[Dochmiac]] *[[Galliambic]], a relatively rare form of which ''Carmen'' 63 by [[Catullus]] is the only complete example from antiquity
{{DEFAULTSORT:Classical meters}} [[Category:Arts-related lists]] [[Category:Poetic rhythm]] [[Category:Stanzaic form]]

page.title: Musicians Hall of Fame and Museum

revision.text:
{{Infobox Museum |name = Musicians Hall of Fame and Museum |image = Edited outside sin.jpeg |imagesize = |caption = New Location for the Musicians Hall of Fame and Museum in Nashville, TN |map_type = |map_caption = |latitude = |longitude = |established = 2006 |dissolved = |location = 401 Gay Street
[[Nashville]], [[Tennessee]] 37219
USA |type = [[Hall of Fame]] and [[Museum]] |visitors = |director = Joe Chambers |curator = |publictransit = |website = [http://www.musicianshalloffame.com/ www.musicianshalloffame.com] }} [[File:Musicians Hall of Fame Logo.jpeg|thumb|Official Logo]] The '''Musicians Hall of Fame and Museum''' (MHOF) honors all musicians regardless of genre or instrument. The MHOF timeline starts with the beginning of recorded music and inductees are nominated by current members of the [[American Federation of Musicians]] and by other music industry professionals. == First museum == The museum first opened June 6, 2006 at 301 6th Ave. S., [[Nashville, Tennessee]] Exhibits consisted of instruments owned and played by well-known artists as well as behind-the-scenes session musicians. These musicians were often the house studio musicians in cities such as [[Memphis, Tennessee|Memphis]], [[Los Angeles]], [[Detroit]], [[Nashville]], [[Muscle Shoals]] and [[New York City]]. These musicians were often the unsung heroes behind the hits of many great artists. These relatively small groups of players often recorded the majority of hits in the 1950s, 1960s, 1970s and 1980s. The museum was voted venue of the year by the [[Meeting Professionals International]] in 2008. == Inductees == 2007 (1st Annual) – [[The Funk Brothers]], [[The Nashville A-Team]], [[The Wrecking Crew (music)|The Wrecking Crew]], [[The Blue Moon Boys]], [[The Memphis Boys]], [[The Tennessee Three|The Tennessee Two]]. The inaugural ceremony was highlighted by the performances of [[Garth Brooks]], [[Vince Gill]], [[Peter Frampton]], [[George Jones]], [[Amy Grant]], [[Rodney Crowell]], [[B.J. Thomas]], and [[Dobie Gray]] honoring the evenings inductees. 2008 (2nd Annual) – [[Billy Sherrill]], [[The Crickets]], [[Al Kooper]], [[Duane Eddy]], [[The Memphis Horns]], [[Booker T and the MGs]], The [[Muscle Shoals Rhythm Section]] & Friends. [[Keith Richards]], [[Kid Rock]], [[Phil Everly]] and [[Lee Ann Womack]] were among the performers to welcome the inductees. Richards joined The Crickets on stage for a performance of Holly's "Don't Fade Away," which [[The Rolling Stones]] covered in 1964. 2009 (3rd Annual) – [[Chet Atkins]], [[Toto (band)|Toto]], [[Victor Feldman]], [[Charlie Daniels]], [[Fred Foster]], [[Billy Cox]], [[Paul Riser]], [[Dick Dale]]. Toto was joined on stage by [[Rascal Flatts]] to perform "Rosanna," "Hold The Line," "I'll Be Over You" and "Africa". [[Steve Wariner]], [[Paul Yandell]], [[Tony Joe White]] and [[Beach Boys]] guitarist [[Al Jardine]] were among the other performers at the ceremony. 2014 (4th Annual) – After a four-year absence due to relocating, the 2014 Induction Ceremony was held in their new location on January 28, 2014. The new inductees were [[Barbara Mandrell]], [[Peter Frampton]], [[Randy Bachmann]], [[Stevie Ray Vaughan]] and [[Double Trouble (band)|Double Trouble]], Corki Casey O'Dell, Velma Smith, [[Will Lee (bassist)|Will Lee]], [[Ben Keith]], Jimmy Capps, [[Buddy Guy]], [[Mike Curb]], and Rock legend [[Roy Orbison]] was also honored with a special posthumous honor - the 2014 "iconic riff" award for the famous guitar lick in his hit "Pretty Woman." http://blogs.tennessean.com/tunein/2013/11/04/musicians-hall-of-fame-to-induct-barbara-mandrell-peter-frampton-more/ 2016 (5th Annual) - Musicians Hall of Fame held its 5th annual Induction Ceremony and Concert. Inductees included: [[Garth Brooks]] and his studio musicians [[The G-Men]], the studio musicians from [[Sigma Sound Studio in Philadelphia]], "Iconic Riff" winner [[Don Felder]] formerly with the Eagles for Hotel California, [[Ricky Skaggs]], "posthumously" [[Jerry Reed]], producer [[Allen Reynolds]], engineers [[Lou Bradley (recording engineer)|Lou Bradley]], [[Ron 'Snake' Reynolds]], [[Joe Tarsia]], and [[Mark Miller (recording engineer)|Mark Miller]]. Special guests included: [[Kenny G]], [[Bruce Hornsby]], [[Steve Wariner]], [[Russell Thompkins Jr.]] and [[Peter Frampton]]. == Closing and reopening == In February 2010, under the rules of [[eminent domain]], the city of Nashville purchased the MHOF property in order to make room for the [[Music City Center]] (new convention center). On August 29, 2013 the MHOF reopened on the first floor of the historic [[Nashville Municipal Auditorium]] just off the James Robertson Parkway exit at 401 Gay Street, Nashville, TN 37219.http://blogs.tennessean.com/tunein/2013/08/27/musicians-hall-of-fame-reopens-in-nashville-after-three-year-absence/ The 200,000 square foot building houses the historic 10,000 seat Municipal Auditorium. The 68,000 sq. ft. exhibit floor, which was also Nashville's first convention center, will now house the museums artifacts and museum. == References == {{reflist|refs = {{cite news | first = Calvin | last = Gilbert | date = November 27, 2007 | title = Unsung Heroes Honored at Musicians Hall of Fame Induction | publisher = [[Country Music Television|CMT.com]] | url = http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1575159/unsung-heroes-honored-at-musicians-hall-of-fame-induction.jhtml | accessdate = June 14, 2013}} {{cite news | first = Daniel | last = Kreps | date = October 29, 2008 | title = Kid Rock, Keith Richards Help Induct Crickets, Muscle Shoals Into Musicians Hall of Fame | publisher = [[Rolling Stone]] | url = https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/kid-rock-keith-richards-help-induct-crickets-muscle-shoals-into-musicians-hall-of-fame-20081029 | accessdate = June 14, 2013}} {{cite news | first = Calvin | last = Gilbert | date = October 13, 2009 | title = Rascal Flatts Perform With Toto During Musicians Hall of Fame Induction Ceremony | publisher = [[Country Music Television|CMT.com]] | url = http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1623747/rascal-flatts-perform-with-toto-during-musicians-hall-of-fame-induction-ceremony.jhtml | accessdate = June 14, 2013}} {{cite news | first = William | last = Williams | date = May 14, 2013 | title = Musicians Hall of Fame and Museum to open in June | publisher = [[NashvillePost.com]] | url = http://nashvillepost.com/blogs/postbusiness/2013/5/14/musicians_hall_of_fame_and_museum_to_open_in_june | accessdate = June 14, 2013}} {{cite news | first = Nancy | last = Amons | date = May 9, 2013 | title = Musicians Hall of Fame and Museum set to reopen with new exhibits | publisher = [[WSMV-TV]] | url = http://www.wsmv.com/story/22212728/musicians-hall-of-fame-and-museum-set-to-reopen-with-new-exhibits | accessdate = June 14, 2013}} }} ==See also== * [[List of music museums]] == External links == * [http://www.musicianshalloffame.com Official Website] [[Category:Music halls of fame]] [[Category:Halls of fame in Tennessee]] [[Category:Music museums in Tennessee]] [[Category:Museums in Nashville, Tennessee]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 2006]] [[Category:2006 establishments in Tennessee]] [[Category:Culture of Nashville, Tennessee]] [[Category:American Federation of Musicians]]

'''Myrlande Constant''' is a Haitian and [[Haitian Vodou|Vodou]] artist who was born in 1968. Constant is married and the mother of four children.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://indigoarts.com/artist/myrlande-constant|title=Myrlande Constant|last=|first=|date=October 26, 2015|website=Indigo Arts|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=March 6, 2018}}</ref>
== Biography == Constant was born in [[Port-au-Prince]] in [[Haiti]] where, as a teenager, she learned the art of beading while working with her mother in a Port-au-Prince factory making wedding dresses. Once she quit that job she moved on to be one of the most celebrated artists for making Vodou drapo.<ref name="Donald J 2012">Donald J.Cosentino, and Edwidge Danticat, ''In Extremis: Death and Life in 21st-century Haitian Art,'' (Los Angeles, CA: Fowler Museum at UCLA, 2012).</ref>{{rp|p.183}} Constant has taken part in the revolution in the art of drapo-making over the last two decades. She has been making flags since the 1900s. Since the 1900s, there was an abrupt shift in drapo-making, which was primarily a male art form. There are several new designers who are women now, one of them being Myrlande Constant. Because of the impact that Constant has on other people, she influences art making in other individuals, in particular [[Marilyn Houlberg]].<ref>Donald J. Cosentino, "Bicentennial blues," ''African Arts'' 37, no. 3 (2004), 6</ref>
Constant bears witness to her nation's calamities. For example, after the earthquake in Haiti in 2010, the artwork Myrlande made represented the collectivistic society through the things that were going on at the time.<ref name="Donald J 2012"/>{{rp|p.20}}
Her works are densely beaded flags (some as large as six by seven feet). Constant’s flags are much larger than traditional flags. In 2011, Constant participated in a series of exhibitions, workshops, and lectures at [[Brown University]] in [[Providence, Rhode Island]] where she conducted a three-day flag-making workshop.<ref name="Donald J 2012"/>{{rp|p.183}}
== Principal expositions and works == Myrlande Constant had her first sale to Richard A Morse, who was the manager of the Oloffson Hotel in Port-au-Prince. Other subsequent sales of her outstanding Vodou flags were made through the connections of her husband, Charles, who convinced customers and visitors at the hotel to buy her work. Many of Constant’s inspiration of her artwork came from her father who is a Vodou priest and Christian. She states that she has no one to thank but the spirits and God before the spirits. She additionally states that the mystical feelings and aspirations come from her thoughts.<ref name="Donald J 2012"/>{{rp|p.185}} Everything she puts on a flag is there for a reason because the spirit keeps her working. Constant is also inspired by Milo Rigaud’s landmark book called ''Veve''. This book contains symbolic drawings of spirits made on Vodou temple floors. Constant uses that inspiration to remember her memories of Vodou ceremonies and knowledge of the spirits to create her own design in the flags.<ref name="Donald J 2012"/>{{rp|p.185}}
The main process of the making of her flags starts with pencil drawings on white cloth. Second, she sews the sequins and beads to the cloth. Lastly, she incorporates the colors that associate with the spirits. Typically, most of her works are as large as bedspreads depicting various significant events in Vodou and Haitian history through using needle, thread, cloth, and tiny adornments.<ref name="Donald J 2012"/>{{rp|p.185}}
Constant is particularly a well known Haitian and Vodou artist in many parts of the world. Specifically, her piece of the 2010 Haiti earthquake apocalypse was recognized as an immediate potential for becoming one of the 2011 Ghetto Biennale Exhibition in [[New York (state)|New York]]’s most extreme and powerful artistic visions.<ref name="Donald J 2012"/>{{rp|p.9}}
'''''Haiti madi 12 januye 2010''''' (Haiti Tuesday, January 12, 2010)
239 x 249 cm
Private collection
This piece of artwork is made with fabric, beads, and sequins. Myrlande Constant’s tableau depicts the ruins and aftermath of the 2010 earthquake. It was funded by the [[Fowler Museum at UCLA|Fowler Museum]] with funds provided by the Fay Bettye Green Fund to Commission New Work. This piece makes the viewer feel the need to study the miseries and disasters that happen in the human life. The chaoticness of the imagery resembles how chaotic the actual event was in 2010. The visual characteristics include a border of crossbones and skulls, and angels and God looking down on the situation resembling the prophet Ezekiel’s vision of dry bones: “The hand of the Lord was on me, and he brought me out by the Spirit of the Lord and set me in the middle of the valley, it was full of bones. [[Ezekiel]] 37:1).” Other aspects of this piece include homes, churches, and vodou temples all being reduced to rubble. Dogs and pigs gnaw on the unburied unprotected human remains. The Catholic Archbishop Serge Miot, who is a man of [[God]], lies dead under the fallen roof of his cathedral with a hand on a bible. Other individuals in the piece are shown as Vodouists who either carry a child in their arms, or wheelbarrow the dead and wounded to the appropriate destinations as a summoning mortal to the hand of their maker in the call of Gabriel. More individuals either pick up the ruins, or sink to the ground as if remaining upright on solid earth is not an option. Constant’s piece depicted a meaning that explained the suffering as ultimately, just as with life, letting death go on. Looking forward to Ash Wednesday being faithful, and having anticipation on Eastertide’s Resurrection were things that Constant reminded the victims of. The victims were shown “Remember that thou art dust, and to dust thou shalt return”. And so, too the Gede will rise up to their feet, shake off the dirt, adjust their glasses, straighten their hats, grab their canes and crutches, and dance.<ref name="Donald J 2012"/>{{rp|p.141}}
'''''La Sirene,'' 2002'''
31’’ x 51’’
Private collection
The La Sirene is made with beads, sequins, and faux pearls on satin. This flag depicts a coquettish spirit who glides through the sea holding flowers, and a handheld mirror close by. There is a legend that states the spirit pulls women under water to get the transformational gift of healing power.<ref name="Donald J 2012"/>{{rp|p.183}}
'''''Simbi Andezo'', 1996'''
36.5’’ x 34.5’’
Private collection
The Simbi Andezo is made of beads and faux pearls on satin. The image dramatically depicts a male ''Iwa'' as a regal female in a white gown. There are flowers that fall from her hands. Simbi is seen as a healer who uses plants for the healing of medicine, which also represents the power of water.<ref>Candice Russell, ''Masterpieces of Haitian Art: Seven Decades of Unique Visual Heritage,'' (Atglen, PA: Schiffer Publishing, 2013), 186.</ref>
'''''Carrefour'''''
21.8’’ x 33.5’’
[[Waterloo Center for the Arts]]
This flag is made with cloth, sequins, and beads. It is shown with mainly bright purple beads with three symbols going from top to bottom. The word “Carrefour” is seen in the lower left corner made with blue beads. “Le8banedre3 leis” is seen in the lower right corner with blue beads. A bright green satin cloth border is around the outside.<ref>Waterloo Center for the Arts Database, “2001.0058” CARREFOUR, ''Myrlande Constant'', n.d. Cloth, sequins, beads, Waterloo Center for the Arts, Unpublished, Assessed 02/06/2018.</ref>
'''''Voodoo Ceremony Flag'''''
27’’ x 60’’
[[Waterloo Center for the Arts]]
The Voodoo Ceremony Flag is made with cloth, sequins, and beads. This large flag depicts a voodoo ceremony with a large group of people. This includes a drum player, two nude females, baron, food, and libation. There is a cloth border in purple with small blue flowers and green leaves.<ref>Waterloo Center for the Arts Database, “2001.0064” VOODOO CEREMONY, ''Myrlande Constant'', n.d. Cloth, sequins, beads, Waterloo Center for the Arts, Unpublished, Assessed 02/06/2018.</ref>
'''''Al Dalaflmbo-Negrel’a L’arch en Clfi'''''
18.75” x 31.75”
[[Waterloo Center for the Arts]]
This flag or banner is made with cloth, sequins, and beads. It depicts a blonde nude woman with green snakes wrapped around her body. The woman is seems to be in front of a green drawn curtain with a black background behind it, and voodoo symbols on each side.<ref>Waterloo Center for the Arts Database, “2007.0222” AL DALAFLMBO_NEGREL’A, ''Myrlande Constant'', n.d. Cloth, sequins, beads, Waterloo Center for the Arts, Unpublished, Assessed 02/06/2018.</ref>
'''''Saint Patricke'''''
31.6’’ x 24.75”
[[Waterloo Center for the Arts]]
Saint Patricke is made of cloth, sequins, and beads. It is a St. Patrick Flag showing St Patrick in a green robe carrying a yellow staff and stepping on snakes. His hand is guiding the snakes towards the water.<ref>Waterloo Center for the Arts Database, “2007.0271” SAINT PATRICK, ''Myrlande Constant'', n.d. Cloth, sequins, beads, Waterloo Center for the Arts, Unpublished, Assessed 02/06/2018.</ref>
'''''Erzulie Freda'''''
26’’ x 22.5’’
[[Waterloo Center for the Arts]]
This is a beaded flag that depicts [[Erzulie Freda]] based on an image on the Mater Dolorosa/Virgin of Sorrows chromolithograph. She is seen as robed in blue as she holds a staff and has various jewels around her. Many objects around her are in the shape of hearts. The entire flag is heavily beaded with a blue cloth border.<ref>Waterloo Center for the Arts Database, “2015.0034” ERZULIE, ''Myrlande Constant'', n.d. Beads, Waterloo Center for the Arts, Unpublished, Assessed 02/06/2018.</ref>
'''''Ogou O Lishana-Gane Gre Jupi Tertannerre'''''
18.5” x 27”
[[Waterloo Center for the Arts]]
The beaded flag is originated from Haiti and depicts a rooster in the center of a large oval covering the center of the flag. A cup and bottle are placed next to the rooster. The border on the outside is orange.<ref>Waterloo Center for the Arts Database, “2015.0054” OGOU, ''Myrlande Constant'', n.d. Beads, Waterloo Center for the Arts, Unpublished, Assessed 02/06/2018.</ref>
'''''Omnipresen Ciadvivn'''''
21’’ x 19’’
[[Waterloo Center for the Arts]]
This is a sequined and beaded flag showing a dramatic image of an old testament deity. The flag shows a fair skinned, white-haired figure in the middle with his hands extended outwards. There is an eye at his torso with rays of color extending out from the eye in all directions. The scale on one side shows a scale with a devil and an angel. The cloth has a thin white border and a thick blue border around the outside.<ref>Waterloo Center for the Arts Database, “2015.0061” OMNIPRESEN, ''Myrlande Constant'', n.d. Sequins, beads, Waterloo Center for the Arts, Unpublished, Assessed 02/06/2018.</ref>
'''''Erzulie Freda'''''
52” x 53”
[[Waterloo Center for the Arts]]
Erzulie Freda is a densely beaded flag with a blue satin border that depicts the individual, Erzulie Freda. The background is green. There is a large gold heart at the front and also to the lower right side of the figure.<ref>Waterloo Center for the Arts Database, “2015.0071” ERZULIE, ''Myrlande Constant'', n.d. Beads, Waterloo Center for the Arts, Unpublished, Assessed 02/06/2018.</ref>
'''''Dambalah Wedo et Ayda Voir Preeace'''''
51’’ x 56.5’’
[[Waterloo Center for the Arts]]
This is a sequined flag that originated from Haiti. The flag depicts Dambalah wedo. Ayda along with other spirits are shown in the forest. It is a gold background with a mauve satin border.<ref>Waterloo Center for the Arts Database, “2015.0109” DAMBALAH, ''Myrlande Constant'', n.d. Sequins, Waterloo Center for the Arts, Unpublished, Assessed 02/06/2018.</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Norse mythology in popular culture]]; added [[Category:Norse mythology in art and literature]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox book | name = Norse Gods and Giants | image = | caption = | author = [[Ingri and Edgar Parin d'Aulaire]] | illustrator = The d'Aulaires | cover_artist = | country = United States | genre = [[Children's literature]], [[mythology]] | publisher = [[Doubleday (publisher)|Doubleday]] | pub_date = 1967 | media_type = Print (hardcover) | pages = 154 pp | oclc = 303177 | isbn = 978-0385072359 |isbn_note= (1967)
{{ISBN|0385049080}} (1986)
{{ISBN|159017125X}} (2005) | congress = {{plainlist| * BL860 .D355 1967 [http://lccn.loc.gov/67019109 "Norse gods and giants"]. (1967). Library of Congress Catalog Record. Retrieved 2013-07-12. * BL860 .D355 1986 [http://lccn.loc.gov/86011677 "D'aulaires' Norse gods and giants"] (1986). LC catalog record. Retrieved 2013-07-12. * BL860 .D355 2005 [http://lccn.loc.gov/2004029214 "D'Aulaires' book of Norse myths"]. (2005). LC catalog record. Retrieved 2013-07-12. }} | dewey = 293/.13 }} '''''Norse Gods and Giants''''' is a children's book written and illustrated by [[Ingri and Edgar Parin d'Aulaire]] and published by [[Doubleday (publisher)|Doubleday]] in 1967. It was reissued by Doubleday in 1986 as ''d'Aulaires' Norse Gods and Giants'' and by [[New York Review Books]] in 2005 as ''d'Aulaires' Book of Norse Myths''. The 154-page book is organized as a collection of 30 [[Norse myths]], with color illustrations throughout, from "The first gods and giants" and "The creation of the world" to "Ragnarokk, the destiny of the gods" and "A new world". The 2005 [[Library of Congress]] catalog summary called it a companion to ''Ingri and Edgar Parin d'Aulaire's Book of Greek myths'', published by Doubleday in 1962, a 192-page collection of 46 [[Greek myths]].[http://www.worldcat.org/title/ingri-and-edgar-parin-daulaires-book-of-greek-myths/oclc/000303182 "Ingri and Edgar Parin d'Aulaire's Book of Greek myths"] (first edition). WorldCat. Retrieved 2013-07-12. The Greek and Norse collections are the couple's second and third most widely held works in [[WorldCat]] libraries, after their [[Caldecott Medal]]-winning [[picture book]] ''Abraham Lincoln'' (Doubleday, 1957).[http://worldcat.org/identities/lccn-n50-037215 "D'Aulaire, Ingri 1904-1980"]. WorldCat. Retrieved 2013-07-12. ==See also== {{Portal bar |Children's literature |Mythology }} ==References== {{reflist |25em {{cite web |title=''D'Aulaires' Book of Norse Myths'', by Ingri and Edgar Parin d'Aulaire |author=James Hynes |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/12/18/books/review/18hynes.html |accessdate=2012-04-16 |date=December 18, 2005}} }} ==External links== * [http://www.worldcat.org/title/daulaires-norse-gods-and-giants/oclc/240042931/editions?start_edition=11&sd=asc&se=yr&referer=di&editionsView=true&fq= Formats and Editions of D'aulaires' Norse gods and giants] at [[WorldCat]] [[Category:American picture books]] [[Category:Children's non-fiction books]] [[Category:Norse mythology in art and literature]] [[Category:1967 children's books]] [[Category:Doubleday (publisher) books]] {{child-picture-book-stub}}

'''Nuclear art''' was an artistic tendency developed by some artists and painters, after the bombings of [[Hiroshima]] and [[Nagasaki]].
==Conception and origins== In the days, weeks and years following the atomic bombing of Japan, trained and untrained artists who survived the bombings began documenting their experiences in artworks.<ref name="MIT Ground Zero">{{cite web |last1=Dower |first1=John |title=Ground Zero 1945: Pictures by Atomic Bomb Survivors |url=http://ocw.mit.edu/ans7870/21f/21f.027/groundzero1945/gz_essay01.html |website=MIT Visualizing Cultures - Ground Zero 1945 |publisher=[[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] |accessdate=17 November 2015 }}</ref> The U.S. occupation authorities controlled the release of photographs and film footage of these events, while photographers and artists on the ground continued to produce visual representations of the effects of nuclear warfare. Photographer [[Yōsuke Yamahata]] began taking photographs of Nagasaki on August 10, 1945 (the day after the bombing), however his photographs were not released to the public until 1952 when the magazine ''[[Asahi Gurafu]]'' published them.<ref name="Unforgettable Fire" >{{cite book |last1=Japanese Broadcasting Corporation (NHK) |title=Unforgettable Fire: Pictures Drawn by Atomic Bomb Survivors|date=1977|publisher=Pantheon Books|location=New York|isbn=978-0394748238 |url=https://archive.org/details/UnforgettableFireDrawingsByAtomicBombSurvivors1967 }}</ref>
===Historical nuclear art in Italy=== In 1948, the artistic movement of [[Eaismo]], published a manifesto illustrating some aspects of the [[atomic age]] and, at the same time, criticizing the industrial use of [[nuclear power]].<ref >G.Favati, V.Fontani, M.Landi, A.Neri, A.S.Pellegrini, Manifesto dell'Eaismo, Società Editrice Italiana, [[Livorno]], 1948</ref>
It was a movement of poetry and painting, founded by the Italian artist [[Voltolino Fontani]], aiming to balance the role of men in a society upset by the danger of [[nuclear radiation]].<ref >{{Cite web |first=Maria |last=Grandinetti |title=Punti programmatici del Movimento Eaista |journal= Arte Contemporanea |location=[[Rome|Roma]] |year=1949 |url=http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/maria-grandinetti_(Dizionario-Biografico)/ |accessdate=1 April 2011 }}</ref> The artistic group was strengthened by the poet [[Marcello Landi]] and by the literary critic Guido Favati. In 1948 Voltolino Fontani depicted the disintegration and fragmentation of an [[atom]] on canvas, by creating the artwork: ''Dinamica di assestamento e mancata stasi''.
In 1951 the painters [[Enrico Baj]] and Sergio Dangelo created the {{illm|Arte nucleare movement|it}}, criticizing and putting the repetitiveness of painting (as an artistic and commercial phenomenon) in discussion.<ref >Luciano Caramel, Arte in Italia, 1945-1960, Vita e Pensiero, [[Milano]] 1994</ref> Plenty of Italian artists, in [[Milan]] and [[Naples]], and foreigners like [[Yves Klein]], [[Asger Jorn]], [[Arman]], [[Antonio Saura]] joined the movement. The main representative of the arte nucleare movement was [[Piero Manzoni]], who in this context, for the first time in his life, put his talent in evidence.<ref >[http://www.pieromanzoni.org/biografia_1933-57.htm, ''link read in April 2011'']</ref>
Unlike Eaismo, recommending artists to pursue painting values (and poetry),<ref >G.Favati, V.Fontani, M.Landi, A.Neri, A.S.Pellegrini, Manifesto dell'Eaismo, Società Editrice Italiana, [[Livorno]], 1948</ref> the arte nucleare movement tried to promote a new form of art in which painting was marginalized.<ref >[http://digilander.libero.it/contemporarea/AAI/ant38, Arman, Baj, Bemporad, Bertini, Colonne, Chapmans, Colucci, Dangelo, De Miceli, D'Haese, Hoeboer, Hundertwasser, Klein, Koenig, Manzoni, Nando, Noiret, A. e G. Pomodoro, Restany, Saura, Sordini, Vandercam ,Verga, Manifesto contro lo stile, Milano, 1959, link read in April 2011]</ref>
===Historical nuclear art in Spain=== In the meantime, Spanish painter [[Salvador Dalì]] published the [[Mystical manifesto]] (1951), putting catholic mysticism and nuclear themes together. In this period Dalì created artworks like [[Idillio atomico]] (1945) and [[Leda Atomica]] (1949).
===Historical nuclear art in France===
In 1949 the French artist [[Bernard Lorjou]] started to paint his monumental artwork “l’age atomique” (The atomic age). The painting was concluded after one year and is now located in the [[Centre Pompidou]].
===Historical nuclear art in the United States===
The painter and photographer [[Eugene Von Bruenchenhein]] painted the artwork “Atomic age” in 1955,<ref >[http://www.ktfineart.com/past/?object_id=86&show=project_images&heading_id=&project_id=90&detail_id=602, link read in 2016]</ref> and other apocalyptical and post apocalyptical paintings up to 1965.
The British sculptor, [[Henry Moore]], created a bronze public sculpture, entitled, [[Nuclear Energy (sculpture)]] (1967) that depicted both the fatality of nuclear weapons as well as celebrated the invention of nuclear energy for use as electrical power. The sculpture is located on the grounds of the University of Chicago, where the first self-sustaining nuclear reaction was produced at the [[Chicago Pile-1]], under the oversight of the Manhattan Project and Enrico Fermi. The sculpture is in the form of a hybrid [[mushroom cloud]] and human skull.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Smithsonian American Art Museum |title=Nuclear Energy (sculpture) |url=http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?session=121J354443PW7.6174&profile=ariall&source=~!siartinventories&view=subscriptionsummary&uri=full=3100001~!296234~!75&ri=3&aspect=Browse&menu=search&ipp=20&spp=20&staffonly=&term=Moore,+Henry+Spencer,+1898-1986,+sculptor.&index=&uindex=&aspect=Browse&menu=search&ri=3 |website=Art Inventories Catalog |publisher=Smithsonian Institution |accessdate=17 November 2015 }}</ref>
==Contemporary approaches to nuclear art==
===Japan=== After the March 2011 accident that caused three nuclear reactors to melt down at the Fukushima Daiichi power plant in Japan, there have been numerous responses by contemporary Japanese artists, including Shigenobu Yoshida, [[Tatsuo Miyajima]], [[Shimpei Takeda]], [[Fuyuki Yamakawa]], Iri and Toshi Maruki, and Hiroshima bomb survivor, Tadasi Tonoshiki.<ref name="WEAD Atomic Legacy Art">{{cite web |last1=Shimizu|first1=Hiroko|title=A new Perspective: Ichi Ikeda |url=http://weadartists.org/japanese-anti-nuclear-art-ichi-ikeda-interview |website=Atomic Legacy Art issue |publisher=WEAD |accessdate=17 November 2015 }}</ref> In 2015 an exhibition was organized in the Fukushima exclusion zone, "Don't Follow the Wind" by curator, Kenji Kubota, that includes the work of 12 international artists.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Quackenbush |first1=Casey |title=The Radioactive Art Exhibit that You Can't Even Go To |url=http://observer.com/2015/07/the-radioactive-art-exhibit-that-you-cant-even-go-to/ |website=Observer |accessdate=17 November 2015 }}</ref>
===North America=== The cultural critic, Akira Mizuta Lippit, has written that the bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki were the most significant photographic and cinematic event of the 20th Century.<ref name="Atomic Light">{{cite book |last1=Lippit|first1=Akira Mizuta |title=Atomic Light (Shadow Optics) |year=2005 |publisher=University of Minnesota Press |location=Milwaukee, MN |isbn=978-0816646111 |url=http://www.upress.umn.edu/book-division/books/atomic-light-shadow-optics }}</ref> There have been numerous exhibitions of photographic works, including the 2015 show, Camera Atomica, at the Art Gallery of Ontario, exhibiting two hundred works.<ref >{{cite web |last1=Art Gallery of Ontario|title=Camera Atomica |url=http://www.ago.net/camera-atomica |publisher=Art Gallery of Ontario Musée des beaux-arts de l"Ontario |accessdate=17 November 2015 }}</ref><ref >{{cite book |last1=O'Brian|first1=John|last2=Bryan-Wilson|first2=Julia|title=Camera Atomica: Photographing the Nuclear World|date=2015|publisher=Black Dog Publishing|location=Canada|isbn=978-1908966483|url=http://blackdogonline.com/photography/camera-atomica.html}}</ref><ref >{{cite journal |last1=Lerager|first1=James |title=A Photo Essay: Nuclear History, Nuclear Destiny |journal=Women Environmental Artists Directory |year=2013 |issue=Atomic Legacy Art |url=http://weadartists.org/a-photo-essay-nuclear-history-nuclear-destiny |accessdate=17 November 2015 }}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=35em}}

Sauvage, Pittura italiana del dopoguerra, Scwwarz Editore, [[Milano]], 1998. *Martina Corgnati, Il Movimento nucleare arte a Milano, edizioni Credito Artigiano, [[Milano]], 1998. * {{Cite journal |title=''Storia della poesia del dopoguerra'' by Luigi Vita |author=Joseph Vittorio Greco |type=Review |journal=[[The Modern Language Journal]] |volume=57 |issue=7 |date=November 1973 |pages=367–368 |publisher=National Federation of Modern Language Teachers Associations |doi=10.2307/324669 |jstor=324669 }}
